SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
  
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

CODE OF ORDINANCES 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, Village of Montgomery, Illinois," and may be so cited. 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of trustees. The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or where the subject matter of context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
    Generally. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the board of trustees may be fully carried out. 
    In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Board, board of trustees, village board. Whenever the words "board," "board of trustees" or "village board" are used, they shall be construed to mean the Board of Trustees of the Village of Montgomery. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be held shall not be counted. Where the day on which an act is to be done or a proceeding held falls on a Sunday or a legal holiday, said act shall be done or proceeding held on the next regular business day. Time shall mean Central Standard Time, except when the State of Illinois is on Daylight Saving Time and then it shall mean Central Daylight Saving Time. 
    Corporate or village limits. The term "corporate limits" or "village limits" shall mean the legal boundaries of the Village of Montgomery. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Kane or the County of Kendall in the State of Illinois, whichever is appropriate. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers generally. Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "village clerk," "chief of police," "president," etc., such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the Village of Montgomery." 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property includes every species of property except real property, as herein described. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Real property shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the village, and shall include all areas thereof embraced between the property lines and dedicated to the public use. 
    Tenant or occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such buildings or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Village shall mean the Village of Montgomery, Illinois. 
    Wholesale, wholesaler, etc. In all cases where the words "wholesale," "wholesaler," or "wholesale dealer" are used in this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, they shall be understood and held to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for purposes of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer who sells in smaller quantities direct to the consumer. 
    Written or in writing shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed and when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments to Code. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the board of trustees. 
Sec. 1-5. - Unauthorized alteration or tampering with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code, in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented thereby. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1-7. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable; and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the village any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor or a violation of this Code, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor or a violation of this Code, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not more than $750.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. Any second offenses committed by the same person within a 12-month period shall result in a fine of not less than $200.00. Any third or subsequent offenses committed by the same person within a 12-month period shall result in a fine of not less than $300.00. An offense processed under this section or under section 1-10 of this Code of Ordinances, or any combination thereof, shall all be considered an offense or offenses for purposes of determining how many offenses a person has committed in a 12-month period. 
(Ord. No. 22, § 15, 6-4-1900; Ord. No. 953, § 2, 6-11-01) 
State Law reference- Limitation on penalties, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1. 
Sec. 1-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 953, § 3, adopted June 11, 2001, repealed § 1-9, Imprisonment until fine and costs paid, as derived from Ord. No. 22, § 18, adopted June 4, 1900. 
Sec. 1-10. - Fines and procedures for minor ordinance violations. 
(a)  Charging document: Any member of the police department, building department, or public works department of the village who would otherwise be authorized to arrest an individual or file a notice to appear against any individual ("defendant" or "violator") for certain ordinance violations may, at said staff member's discretion, in lieu thereof, issue to that individual a ticket (with a voluntary consent or request for trial form as shown on the attached Exhibit A or B) hereto (or such amended version as the chief of police, in consultation with the village attorney shall require), consistent with the provisions of this section 1-10. 
(b)  If said violation is a Type 1 offense as designated hereafter, the fine for such ordinance violations processed in this manner will be $50.00 if paid within seven days of the issuance of the ticket. Thereafter the fine will be $75.00. 
    If said violation is a Type 2 offense as designated hereafter, the fine for such ordinance violations processed in this manner will be $25.00 if paid within seven days of the issuance of the ticket. Thereafter the fine will be $50.00. 
    If said violation is a Type 3 offense as designated hereafter, the fine for such ordinance violations processed in this manner will be $25.00. 
    If said violation is a Type 4 offense as designated hereafter, the fine shall be determined by future ordinance amendment. 
    If said violation is a Type 5 offense as designated hereafter, the fine for such ordinance violations processed in this manner will be as specified in subsection 1-10(f)(5) below. 
    Each day of any such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Process and payments: Failure to comply with the process specified in this section 1-10 shall entitle the police department or building department staff to convert the processing of said violation to the penalties specified in section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances, and shall thereafter be prosecuted by the village attorney, in the circuit court, or such other venue as is applicable, in accordance with Illinois law. 
    The officer issuing said ticket may in his or her discretion request immediate payment of the initial fine. In such cases, if the officer requests immediate payment and the violator agrees to make payment, the officer shall have the violator execute a voluntary consent to administrative settlement as shown on the attached Exhibit A hereto (Exhibit A is on file with the city) which, by execution by the defendant, shall waive his/her rights and authorize the village to apply said payment to the fines assessed herein and close said case without further action. Said amounts shall be deposited into village accounts and used in accordance with village policies and practices regarding voluntary payments of fines to the village. 
    If the violator refuses to sign said voluntary statement the officer may 1) instead issue a ticket in accordance with section 1-8 of this Code, or 2) request a voluntary payment of the Illinois statutory amount of said bond amount (rather than the above schedule of fines), and place said bond funds in a segregated account pending further action required herein, 3) waive immediate payment and issue the ticket without requiring a payment. 
(d)  Further action: If the officer requests payment and payment is received (but no voluntary consent is executed by the violator), the police department shall deposit said amounts in a segregated account. If during the next 30 days a voluntary consent is executed by the violator consenting to administrative settlement of the case and sent to the police department, the police department shall apply the amount of said fine against the amount of said bond and transfer said fine amount into the general accounts of the village per subsection 1-10(c) above. To the extent of any over payment, the village shall refund any overpayments to the violator. If after 30 days, no voluntary consent is received, the officer shall convert said ticket pursuant to section 1-8 and transmit said bond amount to the circuit clerk's office in accordance with established procedures. 
(e)  Failure to pay: If after issuance of a ticket pursuant to this section a defendant, refuses payment, the police department may 1) convert said ticket pursuant to section 1-8 hereof, or 2) if the defendant is a village resident, the officer shall also issue the defendant a "Notice of Violation and Request for Trial" as shown on the attached Exhibit B hereto (Exhibit B is on file with the city). Pursuant to said form, if a resident defendant disagrees with the officers conclusion that the defendant violated the ordinances of the village, the resident defendant shall deliver to the village an executed notice of violation and request for trial from requesting a trial. If the resident defendant executes and delivers the request for trial, the village shall thereafter convert the ticket pursuant to section 1-8 hereof and send the resident defendant a notice to appear in court (to allow for a trial pursuant to court rules). If the resident defendant fails to deliver such a request for trial within 30 days after issuance, the resident defendant shall be conclusively deemed to have violated the section of the ordinances specified in the notice and the village shall impose the amount of said fine against the resident defendant's village services account pursuant to section 2-10 of the Village Code. 
(f)  (1)  Offenses to be processed according to the provisions of this section as Type 1 offenses include but are not limited to the following:

Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Compensation of president. 
    The president of the village shall receive compensation in the amount of $700.00 per month for his/her salary for the office of village president, said salary to commence in fiscal year 1989-90, beginning May 1, 1989. The salary of the president shall be increased to $800.00 per month commencing in fiscal year 1991-92, beginning May 1, 1991. Commencing on the start of the term of office for the village president elected in 2011, the president of the village shall receive compensation in the amount of $900.00 per month for his/her salary for the office of village president. 
(Ord. No. 250, § 1, 12-9-68; Ord. No. 250, § 1, 4-15-69; Ord. No. 323, § 1, 5-27-74; Ord. No. 459, § 1, 12-22-80; Ord. No. 516, 1-14-85; Ord. No. 603, 11-28-88; Ord. No. 1365, § 1, 4-28-08) 
State Law reference- Compensation of president, 65 ILCS 5/3-13-6. 
Sec. 2-2. - Compensation of trustees. 
    Each trustee shall receive as compensation the sum of $4,800.00 per year, which shall be paid at the rate of $400.00 per month, which salary will commence in fiscal year 1989-90, beginning May 1, 1989. The salaries of the trustees shall be increased to $6,000.00 per year, which shall be paid at the rate of $500.00 per month, commencing in fiscal year 1991-92, beginning May 1, 1991. Commencing at the start of the term of office for those village trustees elected in 2011, those trustees elected in 2009 and 2011 shall receive compensation in the amount of $600.00 per month for his/her salary for the office of village trustee. 
(Ord. No. 250, § 2, 12-9-68; Ord. No. 250, § 2, 4-15-69; Ord. No. 323, § 1, 5-27-74; Ord. No. 459, § 1, 12-22-80; Ord. No. 494, 2-7-83; Ord. No. 516, 1-14-85; Ord. No. 603, 11-28-88; Ord. No. 1365, § 1, 4-28-08) 
State Law reference- Compensation of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3-13-7. 
Sec. 2-2.1. - Compensation of clerk. 
    The village clerk shall receive as compensation the sum of $6,000.00 per year payable at the rate of $500.00 per month, which salary shall commence in fiscal year 1989-90, beginning May 1, 1989. Commencing on the start of the term of office for the village clerk elected in 2011, the clerk of the village shall receive compensation in the amount of $600.00 per month for his/her salary for the office of village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 516, 1-14-85; Ord. No. 602, 10-11-88; Ord. No. 603, 11-28-88; Ord. No. 1365, § 1, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 2-2.2. - Duties of village administrator. 
    The village administrator shall be chief administrative officer of the village and shall be responsible to the village board of trustees for the efficient administration of all affairs of the village and shall exercise management supervision over departments and over all real and personal property belonging to the village. The administrator shall have the following duties: 
(a)  To enforce the laws and ordinances within the Village of Montgomery; 
(b)  To manage personnel and issue, subject to board approval, personnel rules applicable to all village employees. The administrator shall have the following responsibilities: 
Except as to personnel governed by the board of police commissioners, and individuals governed by Illinois law, to appoint, suspend or remove all employees. Department heads may only be appointed or removed subject to board approval. All department heads shall report directly to the village administrator. 
To appoint, suspend or remove all other employees of the village as consistent with the annual budget. 
To conduct and coordinate all employee and director performance evaluations. 
To administer and negotiate all collective bargaining agreements for consideration and approval by the village board. 
(c)  To attend all open meetings of the board of trustees and advise the board of pending decisions of public policy, with the right to participate in discussions, but with no right to vote. 
(d)  To prepare, submit and administer the annual budget and capital program. 
(e)  To appoint or designate, with notification to the village president and board of trustees, an acting administrator during his absence. 
(f)  To act as the purchasing agent for all village offices and departments. The administrator may delegate some or all of the duties as purchasing agent to another officer or employee provided that such delegation shall not relieve the administrator of the responsibility for the proper control of those duties. The village administrator shall have the power to enter into agreements with contractors on any contract, agreement or change order, unless otherwise prohibited by law. The village administrator shall only have such authority where the total amount of said contract or agreement is $20,000.00 or less (or the cumulative amount for all change orders on a given project is $20,000.00 or less) and the item is either a) budgeted (generally or specifically) and used in the ordinary course of village business or b) an emergency. The village administrator shall report to the board any such contract, agreement or change order entered into, within 30 days of execution of such contract, agreement or change orders. The village administrator shall have full authority to bind the Village of Montgomery up to said amounts, unless otherwise prohibited by law. 
(g)  To recommend to the board of trustees for adoption such measures as the administrator may deem necessary or expedient. 
(h)  To perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance or resolution by the board of trustees. 
(i)  Assume the ultimate responsibility for handling and following up inquiries and/or requests for public services from elected and/or appointed officials of the village as well as from the public at large. Evaluate the village's responses to requests for public services and develop goals and strategies for year over year continuous improvement. Develop provisions for public evaluation of the village's typical response to their requests for public services. 
(j)  The board of trustees expressly reserves the right to suspend or remove, at any time, any of the above listed powers from the village administrator that in their absolute discretion may be required from time to time. The right to appointment of any officers or other persons that is vested by Illinois Statute in the village president and/or trustees is hereby reserved to the president and trustees and shall not be affected by the grant of powers delineated above. Any duties or rights not expressly delegated herein are reserved by the corporate authorities to the corporate authorities, without limitation. 
(Ord. No. 602, 10-11-88; Ord. No. 603, 11-28-88; Ord. No. 1505, 8-30-11; Ord. No. 1580, § 1, 7-22-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1505, adopted Aug. 30, 2011, changed the title of § 2-2.2 from "Nonstatutory duties" to "Duties of village administrator." 
Sec. 2-2.3. - Authority of village manager to enter certain contracts, agreements, etc. 
    The village manager shall have the power to enter into agreements with contractors on any contract, agreement or change order, unless otherwise prohibited by law. The village manager shall only have such authority where the total amount of said contract or agreement is $10,000.00 or less, or the cumulative amount for all change orders on a given project is $10,000.00 or less. The village manager shall report to the board any such contract, agreement or change order entered into, within 30 days of execution of such contract, agreement or change orders. The village manager shall have full authority to bind the village up to said amounts, unless otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 917, § 1, 9-25-00; Ord. No. 981, § 1, 2-11-02) 
Sec. 2-3. - Board of local improvements. 
    There is hereby created a board of local improvements in and for the village, which board shall consist of the president of the board of trustees and four additional individuals to be appointed by the president and confirmed by the board of trustees. Said individuals shall serve until their successors shall be appointed and qualify. The board of local improvements shall perform all functions incumbent upon and exercise all the rights of a board of local improvements, all as provided in and by 65 ILCS 5/9-2-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 158, § 2, 10-5-59; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 7-10-00) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 17; water, Ch. 20. 
Sec. 2-3.1. - Letters of credit and performance bonds. 
(a)  All letters of credit and performance bonds required by the village shall be in substantially the same format as the form on file with the village clerk, as may be amended from time to time. All letters of credit must be in an amount of 110 percent of the cost of the project. 
(b)  No letter of credit shall be accepted by any official of the village that does not comply with the form set forth in this section, unless the submitted form has been approved in writing by the village attorney. Performance bonds shall only be accepted if the form has been approved in writing by the village attorney and must be in an amount of 110 percent of the cost of the project. In either case, the plans or specifications for the improvement which result in the requirement for a letter of credit shall include an easement of access (acceptable to the village attorney) onto the property in question for the village to complete the improvements specified in the letter of credit and/or performance bond. 
(c)  Letter of credit and/or performance bonds (hereinafter collectively referred to as "letter of credit" or letter of credits") reduction/release requests may be made using the following procedure: 
(1)  The developer or applicant for the project in question must submit a written request with supporting documentation to the director of community development which shall include the following: 
a.  A cover letter formally requesting a reduction or release of the letter of credit. 
b.  An engineer's payment request or similar statement indicating specifically what items have been completed. 
c.  Certifications by the developer that all improvements have been satisfactory installed in accordance with the village's ordinances and requirements. 
d.  Waivers of lien from the contractors. 
(2)  Upon review of the supporting documentation by the village engineer a letter will be furnished to the director of community development recommending approval of the requested reduction/release, a reduction to a revised amount or denial of the request. 
(3)  If the village engineer recommends either approval of the request or a reduction to a revised amount, and after concurrence from village staff that the recommendation is acceptable, the request will be forwarded to the village's development committee for recommendation to the village board. If the next regularly scheduled development committee meeting is canceled, then the request will be taken to the committee-of-the-whole meeting. 
a.  Letter of credits that have been issued in order to gain a temporary certificate of occupancy, as required in section 6-35, or for public improvements (i.e., water main, storm sewer, street extension, etc.) for individual site development projects (i.e., a commercial project such as construction of a pharmacy building and site) are not required to go through the development committee and village board review and approval process. These letter of credits reduction requests can, but are not required to, be reviewed and approved by staff. The village staff has the right (in their discretion) to require any or all letter of credit reduction or release requests to go through the development committee and village board review and approval process. 
(4)  The village board shall then take action on the development committee's recommendation at their next board meeting and shall either approve, deny or modify the recommendation. These provisions do not grant an applicant a right to a reduction or release. The village board retains full authority using its discretion to refuse a partial reduction of a letter of credit. The village board retains full authority to refuse a release of a letter of credit unless release is mandated by Illinois law. 
(5)  If approval is granted, a letter will be sent to the developer from the village's deputy clerk at the direction of the director of community development requesting a new or amended letter of credit (if a reduction or revision was approved) or releasing the letter of credit. 
(Ord. No. 478, §§ 1, 2, 2-22-82; 1433, § 1, 9-14-09; Ord. No. 1821, § 1, 9-10-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 478, adopted Feb. 22, 1982, was nonamendatory of the Code. Codification of §§ 1 and 2 as hereinabove set out in § 2-3.1 was at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 6; planning, Ch. 14; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 2-4. - Duty to disclose ownership of property to village officers. 
    Every agent or other person having charge, control or management, or who collects or receives the rents of any lands, premises or other property in the village, shall disclose the name or names of the owner or owners of such land, premises or property or the name or names of the person or persons for whom such agent or other person is acting, upon application being made therefor by any inspector, agent or police officer of the village. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 1, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 2-5. - Building and grounds committee: Created; composition; appointments; authority. 
(a)  There is hereby created a building and grounds committee. 
(b)  The building and grounds committee shall consist of a chairman and two additional members, who shall be appointed by the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(c)  The building and grounds committee shall have the authority to prepare and propose rules and regulations pertaining to the use and maintenance of the village hall and grounds in the village, which rules and regulations shall be submitted to the board of trustees for their approval by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 288, 2-14-72) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 288, being nonamendatory of this Code, was codified as § 2-5(a)-(c) at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 2-6. - Deputy clerk. 
(a)  Office created. There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk for the Village of Montgomery, Illinois. 
(b)  Appointment. The deputy clerk will be appointed by the village clerk. 
(c)  Duties. Upon the written direction of the village clerk, the deputy clerk will perform the duties of the village clerk only in the absence of the village clerk. 
(d)  Compensation. The compensation of the deputy clerk will be established in the annual appropriation ordinance. 
(e)  Limitation. The deputy clerk shall not work more than 200 hours in any fiscal year without prior approval of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 327, §§ 1-4, 8-12-74; Ord. No. 342, 6-23-75) 
Sec. 2-7. - Voluntary annexation procedures. 
(a)  All voluntary petitions for annexation shall contain therein, in addition to the necessary statutory requirements, a request for zoning, and shall have attached thereto an accurate map of the territory to be annexed. 
(b)  All voluntary petitions for annexation shall be referred to the plan commission of Montgomery, for public hearing and for its written report and recommendation. 
(c)  The public hearing provided herein shall not be required when the voluntary petition for annexation and request for zoning has been filed pursuant to the terms of a pre-annexation agreement, when a public hearing has been previously held on the pre-annexation agreement itself. 
(d)  All voluntary petitions for annexation shall be referred to the village engineer for an on-site inspection of the property to be annexed, including but not limited to inspection of sanitary sewers, stormwater drainage, pavements and sidewalks, and for his written report and recommendation. 
(e)  All voluntary petitions for annexation shall be referred to the village building official for an on-site inspection of the property to be annexed, including but not limited to all structures and improvements thereto, and his written report and recommendation. 
(f)  No property shall be annexed to the Village of Montgomery without the village board of trustees having first received a written report and recommendation from the plan commission, the village engineer, and the building official. 
(Ord. No. 389, §§ 1-5, 4-24-78; Ord. No. 395, 8-14-78) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 389, §§ 1-5, adopted Apr. 24, 1978, as amended, did not specifically amend the Code. Codification herein as § 2-7 was, therefore, at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-8. - Village collector. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created the office of village collector. The village clerk may hold the office of village collector. 
(b)  Duties and powers. The village collector shall have all the duties and powers as provided by statute, including the duty to pay over to the village treasurer all money collected from any source whatever on at least a weekly basis. 
(c)  Reports. The village collector shall make such reports as requested from time to time by the village board and must present an annual report between the first and tenth of April of each year, showing what money has been received, the source thereof and any balances remaining uncollected. 
(d)  Compensation. The village collector shall receive, as compensation, a sum to be set by the board of trustees annually in the village appropriation ordinance. Such compensation shall be in addition to any salary received as village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 692, §§ 1-4, 3-22-93) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 692, adopted Mar. 22, 1993, did not specifically amend this Code, hence, inclusion as § 2-8 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-9. - Purchase of supplies by bid. 
(a)  Unless otherwise authorized by a vote of two-thirds of the trustees then holding office, the purchase of supplies or materials in excess of $10,000.00, needed for use by the village, shall be by contract awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, after due advertisement, considering conformity with specifications, terms of delivery, and quality and serviceability, except the following: 
(1)  Contracts which by their nature are not adapted to award by competitive bidding; 
(2)  Contracts for supplies or materials which are available only from a single source; 
(3)  Contracts for printing of financial documents, bonds and other evidences of indebtedness; 
(4)  Contracts for the procurement of supplies from any federal, state or local governmental unit or agency thereof or materials and supplies as may be made available through a governmental cooperative purchasing arrangement as may be evidenced by an intergovernmental agreement; 
(5)  Contracts for materials or supplies resulting from a change order for work previously awarded but due to unforseen revisions must be purchased causing expenditures not in excess of $10,000.00; 
(6)  The purchase of repair parts for equipment which are required pursuant to contracts for maintenance or servicing of equipment; or which are purchased from the manufacturer or authorized service agent of that equipment where the provision of parts can best be provided by the manufacturer or authorized service agent; 
(7)  Purchases and contracts for the installation of data processing equipment, telecommunications equipment, interconnect equipment, computers, and related software and services; 
(8)  Contracts for duplicating machines and supplies; and 
(9)  Contracts where funds are expended for supplies in an emergency and such emergency expenditure is approved by three-fourths of the members of the board of trustees. 
(b)  All competitive bids for contracts involving an expenditure in excess of $10,000.00 must be sealed by the bidder and must be opened by a member or employee of the board of trustees at a public bid opening at which the contents of the bids must be announced. Each bidder must receive at least three day's notice of the time and place of the bid opening. For purposes of this section, due advertisement includes, but is not limited to, at least one public notice at least ten days before the bid date in a newspaper published and of general circulation in the municipality. Advertisements for bids shall describe the character of the proposed contract in sufficient detail to enable the bidders thereon to know what their obligations will be, either in the advertisement itself, or by reference to detailed plans and specifications on file at the time of the publication of the first announcement. Such advertisement shall also state the date, time and place assigned for the opening of bids, and that no bid shall be received at any time subsequent to the time indicated in the announcement. Notice shall also be posted at the village hall. 
(Ord. No. 1037, § 1, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 2-10. - Village service accounts. 
(a)  Creation of village service accounts. The director of finance is hereby authorized to create individual village service accounts for each user of village services. Said accounts shall consolidate all commonly used village services including, but not limited to, water billing pursuant to chapter 20, garbage pickup pursuant to chapter 9, any applicable fines and penalties pursuant to section 1-10, and any other amounts owed to the village. 
(b)  When processing payments received for a village service account, the village shall apply all payments in the following order: 
(1)  All outstanding penalties and fines for violations of village codes and ordinances; 
(2)  Garbage pickup; 
(3)  Water service; 
(4)  Any other outstanding amounts. 
(c)  A failure to pay any amounts due under a village service account shall entitle the village to cease provision of all village services. 
(d)  Prior to ceasing all village services, the village shall comply with the shutoff procedures established in sections 20-50 and 20-52 (regardless of whether the basis for the shut off is due to a violation of chapter 20, chapter 9, chapter 1, section 1-10, or other Village Code sections that provide village services. 
(Ord. No. 1500, § 1, 4-25-11; Ord. No. 1727, § 1, 6-13-16) 
Secs. 2-11-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RULES OF PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2-21. - Robert's Rules adopted. 
    Parliamentary procedure shall be covered by Robert's Rules of Order in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with rules adopted by the board of trustees or the statutes of the state. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 8, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-22. - Time, place for regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the board of trustees of the village shall be held in the village hall at 1300 So. Broadway, Montgomery, Illinois, on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at the hour of 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 1, 5-26-69; Ord. No. 286, 1-24-72; Ord. No. 996, § 1, 4-8-02) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 286, being nonamendatory of this Code, was codified as part of § 2-22 at the discretion of the editors. Said ordinance provided the address of the village hall. 
Sec. 2-23. - Special meetings. 
    Special meetings of the village board of trustees may be called by the president or any three trustees in the following manner: 
(a)  The president or such three trustees, as the case may be, shall file in the office of the village clerk a statement in writing setting forth the object and purpose of such special meeting and direct the clerk to give notice of the same. 
(b)  Upon the filing of such statement, the village clerk shall cause such notice to be served personally upon each member of the village board of trustees or delivered to his office or residence at least 24 hours prior to such special meeting, which notice shall set forth the object and purpose of such special meeting and the time and place thereof. No business shall be conducted at such special meeting other than that mentioned in the notice. 
(Ord. No. 282, § 2, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-24. - President to preside; when he may vote. 
    The village president shall preside at all meetings of the board of trustees in accordance with the provisions of this article and the law of the state. The president shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution or motion except: 
(a)  Where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; or 
(b)  Where one-half of the trustees elected have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote; or 
(c)  Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is required by statute to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 3, 5-26-69) 
State Law reference- President to preside, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-2. 
Sec. 2-25. - Chairman pro tem. 
    In the absence of the village president, the village board of trustees may elect a trustee to act as temporary chairman. In such event he shall have only the voice of a presiding officer and a right to vote in his capacity as a trustee on any ordinance, resolution, or motion and shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as chairman pro tem. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 4, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-26. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the corporate authorities shall constitute a quorum to do business. A smaller number of members of the board of trustees, however, may adjourn from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 5, 5-26-69) 
State Law reference- Quorum, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-12. 
Sec. 2-27. - Manner of voting; when proposition to be written, oral. 
    Upon every vote the "yeas" and "nays" shall be called and recorded. Every resolution or ordinance shall be reduced to writing. Motions may be presented orally. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 6, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-28. - Order of business. 
    The order of business at all meetings of the village board of trustees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Roll call. 
(2)  Presentation of minutes of previous meeting. 
(3)  Unfinished business. 
(4)  Presentation of the treasurer's report (first Monday). 
(5)  Presentation of bills (first Monday). 
(6)  Chairmen reports. 
(7)  New business. 
(8)  Miscellaneous business. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 7, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-29. - Agenda. 
    If a trustee desires to speak upon a subject other than regular reports he shall notify the village clerk on or before the Friday noon preceding the meeting of the village board of trustees of the subject to be presented or discussed in order that the village clerk may prepare a written agenda for each member of the board of trustees in advance of such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 9, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-30. - Meetings to be open; speaking by the public. 
    All meetings of the village board of trustees shall be open to the public, but no member of the public shall have the right to seek recognition or to speak before the meeting unless he or she has filed a request so to do with the village clerk not later than the Friday noon preceding the meeting of the village board of trustees at which said matter is to be presented. Such request shall designate the name of the speaker and the subject to be presented. The village board of trustees may limit the time allowed for such recognition and presentation. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 10, 5-26-69) 
State Law reference- Meetings to be open and public, 5 ILCS 120/2. 
Sec. 2-31. - Suspension of rules. 
    The village board of trustees may suspend the rules by a vote of the majority of the trustees present. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 11, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-32. - Sergeant at arms. 
    The village trustees may in their discretion and from time to time appoint a sergeant at arms who shall be a member of the village police department whose duty it would be to keep and maintain dignity and order at the village board meetings upon the orders and instructions given him by the village president or by an action of the majority of the members of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 252, § 12, 5-26-69) 
Sec. 2-33. - Cancellation of regular meeting; payment of village obligations authorized. 
    In the event that a regular meeting of the board of trustees is canceled, the treasurer is hereby authorized to make all necessary payments in the ordinary course of conducting village business until the next meeting of the board of trustees. When the provisions of this section are relied upon by the treasurer to make any payments on behalf of the village, said payments shall be included on the next board of trustees' meeting agenda for ratification by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 922, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 2-34. - Periodic review and destruction of executive session recordings. 
    The village board authorizes the village clerk, or his or her designee, to engage in the periodic review and destruction of any and all audio or video recordings of executive session (closed session) meetings, not less than 18 months old, so long as any and all related written minutes have been approved, in accordance with the requirements set forth in the Open Meetings Act [5 ILCS 120/2.06(c)]. 
(Ord. No. 1697, 11-9-15) 
Secs. 2-35-2-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 2-45. - Policy and purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the village to extend to the eligible employees thereof, effective as of January 1, 1956, the benefits of the Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance System as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the village treasurer shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 112, § 1, 12-5-55) 
Sec. 2-46. - Agreement authorized. 
    The village treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement with the State Employees' Retirement System of the State of Illinois, Social Security Unit, to secure coverage of eligible employees as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 112, § 2, 12-5-55) 
Sec. 2-47. - Withholdings. 
    Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees for the purpose provided in this article, are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 112, § 3, 12-5-55) 
Sec. 2-48. - Employer contributions. 
    Employer contributions and administrative expenses shall be paid to the state agency in accordance with applicable state laws and regulations from amounts appropriated for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 112, § 4, 12-5-55) 
Sec. 2-49. - Records, reports. 
    The village treasurer shall maintain such records and submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 112, § 5, 12-5-55) 
Secs. 2-50-2-64. - Reserved.

(b)  The clerk is directed to promptly file a certified copy of this article with the board of trustees of the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund.

ARTICLE V. - FREEDOM OF INFORMATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1473, adopted Oct. 25, 2010, repealed §§ 2-152-2-161, which pertained to responsible official; public records available for inspection or copying; public records exempt from inspection or copying; nonexempt materials contained in exempt records; dissemination of information about the village; list of records available from the village; procedure for requesting inspection or copying of public records; request for public records-denial; appeal of denial; fees; and derived from Ord. No. 607, adopted March 27, 1989.

Sec. 2-151. - Purpose. 
    Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) officers shall be appointed by the village president (and confirmed by the board of trustees) from time to time and the names and office addresses of such persons shall be displayed on the village website and in a directory at village hall in accordance with state law. All inquiries regarding the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) including requests for inspection and copying of records shall be directed to the designated FOIA officers. The designated FOIA officers shall assemble requested documents and perform acts necessary to ensure the village's compliance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act. 
(Ord. No. 607, § 1, 3-27-89; Ord. No. 1473, § 1, 10-25-10)
