Any such application must be submitted not less than 21 days in advance of the proposed display, distribution or possession of fireworks. Upon receipt of the application, the applicant shall provide such further information as the chief of police may request, and the applicant shall comply with any such request within two business days of the request or the application shall be deemed withdrawn. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application, the chief of police may consult with any persons he deems necessary for the full review and consideration of such application, including the village manager for the Village of Montgomery, the director of public works for the Village of Montgomery, and representatives of any fire protection department or district that services the area where the display, distribution or possession of fireworks is proposed. 
(c)  Should the chief of police decide, in his sole discretion, to issue a permit under this chapter, attached to the permit shall be a copy of the application. The distribution, display or possession of fireworks shall be thereafter limited to activities within the terms of the application and no person not listed on the application shall be permitted to distribute, display or possess fireworks. Permits are not transferable or assignable, and must be presented upon request of any official, agent or employee of the Village of Montgomery or any official, agent or employee of any fire protection department or district having jurisdiction over the area in which fireworks related activities are being undertaken. 
(d)  Any person who applies for or receives a permit for fireworks related activities must immediately inform the chief of police of any material changes in any of the information provided on the application should such changes occur at any time after permit application and before termination of the fireworks related activities. Upon submission of such updates, the chief of police or his designee may suspend or revoke any permit issued. 
(Ord. No. 1275, § 2, 6-26-06) 
Sec. 81/4-7. - Additional restrictions. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued for any fireworks related activities where: 
(1)  Such activity endangers persons, buildings, structures, forests or brush; 
(2)  Such activity proposes the display of fireworks within an unsafe distance of the nearest permanent building, public highway, railroad or other means of travel; 
(3)  Such activity proposes the display of fireworks within an unsafe distance of the nearest aboveground or overhead obstruction; 
(4)  Such activity proposes the display of fireworks supervised by fewer than two qualified persons. For purposes of this section, a qualified person shall be deemed to be a person over the age of 21 years, capable of reading, writing, speaking and understanding the English language, and otherwise competent for the task; the chief of police may specify additional qualities or conditions that are required for a person to be deemed qualified; 
(5)  Such activity proposes the possession, distribution or display of fireworks within the interior of any structure that is not equipped with an automatic sprinkler system and such other safety equipment as shall be required by the chief of police; 
(6)  Such activity proposes the possession, Distribution or display of fireworks within 500 feet of a school, church, hospital or similar institution; or 
(7)  Such activity would violate Illinois Fireworks Law or other applicable local, state or federal law. 
(b)  Irrespective of whether a permit has been issued, it shall be unlawful to engage in fireworks related activity where: 
(1)  Such activity endangers persons, buildings, structures, forests or brush; 
(2)  Such activity violates Illinois Fireworks Law or other applicable local, state or federal law; 
(3)  Such activity requires licensure under Illinois Fireworks Law or any federal law and no person who is both involved in the activity and listed on the permit possesses such current licensure; or 
(4)  Such activity involves the display of fireworks at a time when the wind speed at the location of the display exceeds 20 miles per hour. 
(c)  Any possession, display or distribution of fireworks shall be subject to such further conditions as shall be prescribed by the chief of police, in writing, at the time of issuance of permit. 
(d)  All fireworks shall be secured, maintained and utilized in such a manner as to be free from fire, injury, accidental discharge or theft. 
(e)  Any applicant who receives a permit for the display of fireworks shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the Village of Montgomery and the applicable fire protection department or district with jurisdiction over the area of the display. Prior to the issuance of any permit, the applicant shall be informed of the anticipated costs of such display and shall post with the village police department, an escrow in an amount equal to such anticipated costs. In the event the actual costs incurred exceed the anticipated costs, the applicant shall be responsible for the actual costs, plus any attorney's fees, court costs or other expenses incurred in the recovery of such costs. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the chief of police may waive the payment of costs for displays of fireworks performed by a not-for-profit entity or unit of local government. 
(f)  The chief of police, or any designee chosen by him, may attend any fireworks related activity that is subject to a permit issued by the Village of Montgomery. If the chief of police or his designee believes that any violation of any provision of this chapter or Illinois Fireworks Law is occurring, has occurred, or is about to occur, or if such person believes that the fireworks related activity is endangering persons or property, such person may immediately suspend or revoke the permit issued by contacting the applicant on the cellular telephone number provided on the permit application. Immediately upon receipt of notice of such suspension or revocation, the applicant shall terminate all fireworks related activities and secure any and all fireworks from further display or distribution in a safe fashion. The chief of police or designee may thereafter reinstate such permit and allow such Fireworks related activities to continue if, in such person's sole judgment, it is safe and lawful to do so. 
(Ord. No. 1275, § 2, 6-26-06) 
Sec. 81/4-8. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any fees or charges established herein, any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-8 of this Code for each offense, for each day such offense occurs. In the event of unpermitted display, distribution or possession of fireworks, each individual article of fireworks displayed, distributed or possessed shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1275, § 2, 6-26-06) 
Sec. 81/4-9. - Village chief of police designees. 
    The chief of police may from time to time designate alternate village officials or staff, including but not limited to the village manager or village clerk, to perform all or some of the obligations of the village or any of its officials or staff under this chapter. In the event the chief of police makes such designations, the designees shall have the full authority of the village under this chapter, provided that the chief of police may, at any time, designate alternate officials or staff to perform any role hereunder. Further, for purposes of suspending or revoking a permit due to unsafe conditions or violations of Illinois Fireworks Law or violations of permit conditions under subsection 81/4-7(f) of this chapter, the village manager, village clerk, village chief of police and any sworn police officer of the Village of Montgomery, village director of community development and the village director of public works are hereby appointed as designees of the village with the authority to suspend or revoke a permit. 
(Ord. No. 1275, § 2, 6-26-06) 
Chapter 81/2 - FLOOD HAZARD PREVENTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 385, §§ 1-11, 13-17, adopted Dec. 27, 1977, did not specifically amend the Code, hence codification herein as Ch. 81/2, §§ 81/2-1-81/2-11, 81/2-13-81/2-17, is at the discretion of the editor. Sections 18 and 19 of said Ord. No. 385, pertaining to separability and effective date, are not set out herein. 

Sec. 81/2-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to avoid the hazards to persons and damage to property resulting from flooding and to comply with the rules and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program as promulgated by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, Federal Insurance Administration as provided in the rules and regulations of the Federal Register, Vol. 41, No. 207, Tuesday, October 26, 1976, as amended, and which are hereby adopted by reference, and filed in the office of the city clerk, pursuant to Illinois Law and 65 ILCS 5/11-30-2. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 1, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-2. - Conflicting laws repealed. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed as additional requirements to minimum standards required by other ordinances of the city. In case of conflicting requirements the most restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 2, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-3. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted: 
(a)  Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including but not limited to construction of or substantial improvements to buildings or other structures, the placement of mobile homes, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations. 
(b)  Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland waters, or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
(c)  Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equalled or exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year flood. 
(d)  Base flood elevation means the elevation to mean sea level of the crest of the base flood. 
(e)  Structure means a walled and roofed building including a gas or liquid storage tank that is principally above ground, as well as a mobile home and a prefabricated building. 
(f)  Mobile home means a structure transportable in one or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. For the purpose of this chapter it does not include recreational vehicles or travel trailers. 
(g)  Substantial improvement means any repair, reconstruction, or improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the market value of the structure either before the improvement or repair is started; or if the structure has been damaged, and is being restored, before the damage occurred. The term does not, however, include either: (1) Any project for improvement of a structure to comply with existing state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions, or (2) Any alteration of a structure or site documented as deserving preservation by the Illinois Department of Conservation or listed on the National Register of Historic Places. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 3, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-4. - Flood hazard boundary map. 
    The flood hazard boundary maps Nos. H-01, H-02 dated October 26, 1973, with latest revisions and amendments thereto, delineating A Zones as areas that are susceptible to the base flood as prepared by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, Federal Insurance Administration, are hereby adopted for the purpose of this chapter and filed as a record in the office of the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 4, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-5. - Permit required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall commence any construction, substantial improvement, subdivision of land, placement of mobile homes or other development in areas located in an A Zone without first obtaining a permit from the village engineer. The village engineer shall not issue such permit for any construction, substantial improvement, or other development that does not comply with the provisions of this chapter or that has been denied a permit required by the federal or state law including Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 5, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-6. - Application. 
(a)  Within areas designated as A Zones each application for development shall be accompanied by elevations, in relation to mean sea level, of the lowest habitable floor, including basement, and in the case of floodproofed structures, the elevations to which it will be floodproofed. 
(b)  The village engineer shall require certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that floodproofing methods are adequate to withstand the flood depths, pressures, velocities, impact and uplift forces, and other factors associated with the base flood. 
(c)  The application shall also contain information or certification as reasonably may be required by the village engineer in order to determine eligibility for permits or to enforce the terms of this chapter. 
(d)  The village engineer shall review applications or permits and determine before issuing a permit that the development activity would be reasonably safe from flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 6, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-7. - Base flood elevation. 
    The village board shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize base flood elevation data available from federal, state or other sources until such time as such data has been received from the Federal Insurance Administration. Base flood data received from the Federal Insurance Administration shall take precedence over data from other sources. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 7, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-8. - New construction, substantial improvement standards. 
    All new construction and substantial improvements to structures located in an A Zone shall: 
(a)  For residential structures have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to two feet above the base flood elevation. 
(b)  For nonresidential structures have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated or floodproofed to two feet above the base flood elevation. 
(c)  Be designed or modified and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure. 
(d)  Be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage. 
(e)  Be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage to other properties. 
(f)  Have all structural components below the base flood elevation designed to be watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and such structural components shall be designed to resist hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effects of buoyancy. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 8, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-9. - Mobile home standards. 
(A)  All mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions located in an A Zone shall file evacuation plans indicating vehicular access and escape routes, including mobile home hauler routes with appropriate disaster preparedness authorities. 
(B)  All mobile homes to be placed on a site located in an A Zone shall: 
(1)  Have the lowest floor elevated two feet above the base flood elevation. 
(2)  In the instance of elevation on pilings, have all piling foundations placed in stable soil no more than ten feet apart, and reinforcement shall be provided for piers more than six feet above ground. 
(3)  Have lots large enough to permit steps to the mobile home, and have adequate surface drainage on all sides of the structure. 
(4)  Be placed to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure due to flooding. 
(5)  Be anchored according to the following specifications: 
(a)  Over-the-top ties shall be provided at each of the four corners of the mobile home, with two additional ties per side at intermediate locations and mobile homes less than 50 feet long shall require one additional tie per side; 
(b)  Frame ties shall be provided at each corner of the mobile home with five additional ties per side at intermediate points and mobile homes less than 50 feet long shall require four additional ties per side; 
(c)  All components of the anchoring system shall be capable of carrying 4,800 pounds; and 
(d)  Any additions to the mobile home shall be similarly anchored. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 9, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-10. - Utility standards. 
    All new construction and substantial improvements to utilities located in an A Zone shall provide that: 
(a)  All new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems. 
(b)  All new and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into the floodwaters. 
(c)  All new and replacement on-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 10, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-11. - Subdivision, other development standards. 
    All subdivisions and other developments located in an A Zone shall provide that: 
(1)  All subdivision and other development proposals shall be designed to minimize flood damage to the proposed subdivision or development site as well as to other properties. 
(2)  All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems shall be located, elevated, and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(3)  Adequate drainage shall be provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(4)  For any proposed subdivision or new development greater than five lots or one acre, whichever is the lesser, the applicant shall show the base flood elevation data for each lot or platted parcel. Provided, that if the base flood elevation data is not available the applicant shall compute and provide this information for each lot or platted parcel of a subdivision or new development proposal which is greater than five lots or one acre, whichever is lesser. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 11, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-12. - Reserved. 
Sec. 81/2-13. - Watercourse standards. 
    The village engineer shall notify adjacent communities and the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources and the Federal Insurance Administration prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse. The flood-carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse shall be maintained. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 13, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-14. - Reports, records. 
(a)  The village engineer shall provide the village board, the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources, and the Federal Insurance Administration with an annual report on forms as provided the village by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(b)  The village engineer shall maintain the records of first floor elevations, floodproofing certifications, all variance documents required by section 1910.6 (a) (5) and (6) of the rules and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program, permit applications, and all other records required by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 14, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-15. - Variances. 
    Upon application and after 15 days' notice of a public hearing, the village board may grant a variance of this ordinance subject to compliance with the provisions of section 1910.6(a) of the rules and regulations of the national flood insurance program and such other conditions as the village board deems necessary to comply with the intent of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 15, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-16. - Disclaimer of liability. 
    The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur on rare occasions or the flood height may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This chapter does not imply that development either inside or outside of areas designated as an A Zone will be free from flooding or damage. This chapter does not create liability on the part of the village or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage that results from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision made lawfully thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 16, 12-27-77) 
Sec. 81/2-17. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any person who violates this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than $250.00 nor more than $500.00 and in addition, shall pay all costs and expenses involved in litigation. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 17, 12-27-77) 
Chapter 9 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl generally, Ch. 4; nuisances generally, § 12-3; water system and regulations, Ch. 20. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Offensive accumulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of any property to permit the accumulation or existence upon said premises of any putrid or unsound meat, pork, fish, hides, decayed vegetables or food, manure, filthy ash heaps, garbage, offal, rubbish, dirt or filth of any kind which, by its decay or putrefaction, could or would become offensive to human beings, or detrimental to health, or which, by its existence might harbor rats or other rodents. 
Cross reference- See also, § 9-6. 
Sec. 9-2. - Accumulation, discharge of liquid wastes. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of any property to permit the accumulation upon said premises, or the discharge thereof upon any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place, or upon any private property, of urine, liquid waste from stables, swill, water from privy vaults, waste water, filthy wash water, or any foul or nauseous liquid waste of any kind. 
Sec. 9-3. - Dumping, deposit, etc., of litter prohibited. 
(a)  Exemptions. No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause or permit the dumping, depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding or leaving of litter upon any public or private property in this village, or upon or into any river, lake, pond, or other stream or body of water in this village, [unless] 
(1)  The property has been designated by the village for the disposal of litter, and the litter is disposed of on that property in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations of the village; and 
(2)  The litter is placed into a receptacle or other container intended by the owner or tenant in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of litter; and 
(3)  The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of the property or has first obtained the consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant and does not create a public health or safety hazard, a public nuisance, or a fire hazard; and 
(4)  The person is acting under the direction of proper public officials during special cleanup days; and 
(5)  The person is lawfully acting in or reacting to an emergency situation where health and safety is threatened, and removes and properly disposes of such litter when the emergency situation no longer exists. 
    For purposes of this section, a rebuttable presumption as to the ownership of any item shall exist if at least three pieces of documentation indicating or substantiating such ownership are recovered from among said material. 
(b)  Dumping, deposit, etc., from motor vehicle prohibited; deposit of garbage or refuse in receptacles along public highways. No person shall dump, deposit, throw, discard or otherwise dispose of litter from any motor vehicle upon any public highway, upon any public or private property or upon or into any river, lake, pond, stream or body of water in this village except as permitted under any of paragraphs (1) through (5) of section 9-3(a). Nor shall any person transport by any means garbage or refuse from any dwelling, residence, place of business, farm or other site to and deposit such material in, around or on top of trash barrels or other receptacles placed along public highways or at roadside rest areas. 
(c)  Presumption of violation by operator; throwing, deposit, etc., of litter from motor vehicle. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle not carrying passengers for hire, the presumption is created that the operator of that motor vehicle has violated section [9.3(b)], but that presumption may be rebutted. 
(Ord. No. 685, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 9-4. - Discharging sanitary, industrial wastes to storm drains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to connect or cause to be connected any drain carrying or to carry any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool or industrial waste, or any fixture or device discharging polluted substances, to any storm water drain in the village. 
(Ord. No. 156, § 1, 7-20-59) 
Sec. 9-5. - Disposal of dead animals. 
    All dead animals in the city, other than in lawfully operated slaughterhouses, shall, within 12 hours after the death of the animal, be removed and disposed of by burial or cremation. 
Sec. 9-6. - Unlawful accumulations; notice to remove; failure to obey notice. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this section for any owner of private property to allow garbage and debris to accumulate thereon. 
(b)  The building inspector shall cause a notice to be served upon the owner of any parcel of property whereon garbage or debris has accumulated, of the violation of this section. Said notice shall also require the removal of said garbage or debris within a reasonable period of time, not to exceed 30 days. 
(c)  In the event the garbage or debris is not removed by the owner at the expiration of the time stated in the notice, the corporate authorities will cause the removal of said garbage or debris without further notice to the property owner. Within 60 days after said removal by the corporate authorities, the corporate authorities will cause a lien to be filed on said real estate. Said lien shall be perfected by filing a notice of lien in the office of recorder of deeds in the county in which said real estate is located. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth: 
(1)  The description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof. 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service. 
(3)  The date or dates when the cost and expenses were incurred by the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 314, §§ 1-5, 12-19-73) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 314, enacted Dec. 19, 1973 did not expressly amend this Code; hence, codification as § 9-6 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Cross reference- See also, § 9-1. 
Sec. 9-6.1. - Unlawful to remove recyclable item from container. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, organization or corporation to collect, obtain, possess or pick up any recyclable item deposited for collection from any container placed in front of a residence as part of the village's recycling program, unless such person, firm, organization or corporation is so designated to do so by the village. 
(Ord. No. 685, 9-28-92) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 685, adopted Sept. 28, 1992, added provisions designated as § 9-7. For purposes of classification and to avoid duplicative section numbering, such provisions have been redesignated as § 9-6.1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 9-7-9-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 953, § 3, adopted June 11, 2001, repealed § 9-7, Penalty, derived from Ord. No. 648, adopted Dec. 10, 1990. 
ARTICLE II. - UNHEALTHFUL BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Building regulations generally, Ch. 6. 

Sec. 9-21. - Leasing. 
    Any owner, agent, lessee, or person in possession, charge or control of any building or any part thereof, shall not lease or let the same, or any portion thereof, or allow the same to be occupied by any person as a dwelling, rooming or lodging house, unless such building or such parts thereof are in a clean and wholesome condition as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 2, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-22. - Declared nuisance. 
    Any building or part thereof which, by reason of its physical or unsanitary condition, or of its being infected with disease, be unfit for human habitation, or which from any other cause is a source of sickness among the inhabitants of this village, or which otherwise endangers the public health, is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 3, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-23. - Examination; notice; abatement. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the village president or his duly authorized agent to cause an examination to be made of any building alleged to be a public nuisance for any of the foregoing reasons; such examination to be made by the chief of police of the village or such other agent as the village president shall designate. If the said agent shall find and report to the village president that a public nuisance exists, as defined in the foregoing section, the village president shall serve notice upon the owner of such building, or his agent, or the person in possession, charge or control of such building, directing him to abate the nuisance, and to place the building in a condition that shall not endanger the public health, within such reasonable time as the village president shall prescribe. Upon failure of the person so notified to obey said notice, the village president may after the expiration of the time specified therein, abate the nuisance by ordering the vacation of such building, or part or parts thereof, when such vacation is required by the public health of the village; and if within 30 days after such vacation has been ordered, the building or buildings or any part thereof are not put in a sanitary condition, then said village president shall have the power to order the demolition of such building or buildings or parts thereof, and the chief of police is hereby authorized and instructed to furnish the necessary service for such demolition on the request of the village president. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 4, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-24. - Requiring vacating. 
    Whenever it shall be decided by the village president that any building or part thereof is unfit for human habitation by reason of it being so infected with disease, or from other causes, as to be likely to cause sickness among the occupants, and notice of such decision shall have been affixed conspicuously on the building, or part thereof, so decided to be unfit for human habitation, and personally served upon the owner, agent or lessee, if the same can be found in the state, or the person in possession, charge or control of such building, requiring all persons therein to vacate such building or part thereof for the reasons to be stated therein as aforesaid, it shall be the duty of said village president to see to it that such building or part thereof is vacated within ten days from the date of such notice or within a shorter time (not less than 48 hours in any case) as may be specified in said notice, if in the opinion of said village president such building or portion thereof should be vacated within less than ten days. Said village president shall have the power and authority to call upon the department of police or upon any member thereof for such assistance as may be necessary to enable him to enforce the provisions of this section, and it shall be the duty of any member of the police department so called upon to render such assistance as may be required of him by the village president. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 5, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-25. - General cleanliness, ventilation, temperature. 
    Every owner, lessee or tenant, or manager of any tenement house, lodging house, boardinghouse, rooming house, or manufactory, shall cause every part thereof and its appurtenances to be put, and shall thereafter cause the same to be kept, in a clean and wholesome condition and shall speedily cause every apartment or room thereof in which any person may sleep, dwell or work, to be adequately lighted and ventilated, and if the same is a manufactory shall cause every part thereof in which any person may work to be maintained at such temperature, and be provided with such accommodations and safeguards, as not by any reason of the want thereof, or of anything about the condition of such manufactory or its appurtenances, to cause unnecessary danger or detriment to the health of any person employed therein. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 6, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-26. - Permitting occupancy of cellars, dangerous places. 
    No person having the right and power to prevent the same shall knowingly cause or permit any person to sleep or remain in any cellar, or in any place dangerous or prejudicial to health by reason of want of ventilation or drainage or toilet facilities, or by reason of the presence of any poisonous, noxious or offensive substance or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 7, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-27. - Minimum space required. 
    It shall be the duty of all proprietors, keepers and managers of hotels, boardinghouses, rooming houses, tenement houses and apartment houses to provide at least 300 cubic feet of room or breathing space for each person sleeping in or occupying any part of such building. No person owning or managing any such house or building, either as proprietor or agent shall receive or take in boarders or roomers, unless he shall have for their use within such house or building, the space required in this section, and no person shall become a boarder, roomer or occupant of any such building, not furnishing him or her with the room or space herein required. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 8, 11-4-57) 
Sec. 9-28. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this article, or who resists any agent or officer in the discharge of his duties concerning any of the matters in this article, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 8, 11-4-57) 
Secs. 9-29-9-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GARBAGE AND TRASH[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Garbage disposal in food establishments, § 9-93; junk and junk dealers, Ch. 10. 

Sec. 9-41. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Garbage shall mean all animal debris of every kind as well as fruit and vegetable matter and other putrescible matter. 
    Garden trash shall mean grass, limbs of trees, leaves, hedge clippings, twigs and other foreign material raked from any lot, plot, tract or parcel of land within the village, or cut or removed from any trees within the village. 
    Rubbish shall mean tin cans, glassware, crockery, bottles, rags, old shoes and clothing, wastepaper, ashes, cinders metal, floor sweepings, and other combustible matter, and all other waste other than garbage and garden trash. 
    Village dumps shall mean all premises owned or leased by the village for the purpose of the disposal of garbage, garden trash and rubbish collected from residents of the village. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 1, 11-6-61) 
Sec. 9-42. - Manner of disposal generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any garbage, garden trash, or rubbish other than in a container designed for that purpose and so designed as to prevent said garbage, garden trash, or rubbish from being scattered or blown about. Further, pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-19-5, the village has entered into an exclusive contract for the collection of residential garbage, refuse, and other such similar items. Said contract (or future contracts) entered into by the village shall be the exclusive method for the disposition of residential garbage, refuse, etc., to be allowed within the municipality. All other methods of residential disposition of garbage inconsistent with the village agreements which are entered into from time to time are hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 635, 6-11-90; Ord. No. 980, § 1, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 9-42.1. - Receptacles required; collection. 
(a)  Every owner or his agent, or the occupant of any house, building or apartment in the village wherein persons reside, board or lodge, shall provide for each such house, building or apartment and at all times maintain containers for refuse, garbage, trash or rubbish in a number sufficient to store and handle for disposal the accumulation from each such house, building or apartment. Such container shall not be located in front yards as defined by the zoning ordinance, unless permitted by said zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Garbage, refuse, trash or rubbish containers to be emptied or removed by licensed scavengers of the village within residential areas of the village shall be placed and grounded at the street curb only after 4:00 p.m. on the day prior to the day assigned for pickup; and all empty containers must be removed by 7:00 p.m. on the day of pickup. 
(Ord. No. 352, §§ 1, 2, 2-23-76; Ord. No. 362, 6-14-76; Ord. No. 751, 9-42.1) 
Editor's note- The reader's attention is directed to § 9-45 which, in part, pertains to the subject matter addressed in paragraph (b) above. 
Sec. 9-43. - Preparation of garbage for village disposal. 
    All persons desiring the village or a scavenger under contract with the village to dispose of garbage shall wrap all animal, fruit and other vegetable matter securely in paper and place it in covered cans or covered containers capable in size of being dumped into a truck by one man. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 2, 11-6-61) 
Sec. 9-44. - Requirements for village collection of garden trash. 
(a)  All grass, leaves, hedge clippings, twigs and small limbs shall be placed in a bag specifically designed for yard waste or a reusable garbage container and shall be clearly labeled as yard waste. 
(b)  Limbs or branches too large to be inserted in a bag or garbage can shall be tied in bundles capable of being lifted by one person. 
(c)  Each bag, garbage can or bundle shall have a village yard waste label attached to it. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 3, 11-6-61; Ord. No. 636, 6-11-90) 
Sec. 9-45. - Location of garbage and garden trash for collection. 
    Where there are no through alleys back of the property, all garbage shall be placed in covered cans or covered containers and placed on the parkway or curb in front of the premise from which it originates on the date the garbage is to be collected. Grass and limbs of trees susceptible of being placed in baskets or containers shall also be so placed. Limbs of trees too large to be insertable in baskets or containers shall be neatly piled on the parkway or curb ready for collection as hereinabove directed. Where there are alleys, all garbage and garden trash shall be placed as herein directed in said alley. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 4, 11-6-61) 
Sec. 9-46. - Collecting days. 
    Collecting days shall be such as may from time to time be fixed by the village board for any given area of the village. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 5, 11-6-61) 
Sec. 9-47. - Report of violations. 
    The superintendent of streets or his duly authorized agent is hereby authorized and directed to report immediately any violations of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 8, 11-6-61) 
Secs. 9-48-9-59. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 953, § 3, adopted June 11, 2001, repealed § 9-48, Penalty, derived from Ord. No. 647, adopted Dec. 10, 1990. 
ARTICLE IV. - FOOD AND FOOD HANDLERS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- General cleanliness of alcoholic liquor establishments, § 3-35; diseased employees in alcoholic liquor establishments, § 3-36. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate food, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-60. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the village clerk or his deputy to enforce the provisions of this article and he is hereby authorized and empowered from time to time to inspect and examine all retail food establishments, as defined herein, for the purpose of ascertaining whether this article and all ordinances of the village and laws of the state, relative to retail food establishments, are being complied with. It shall be the duty of every owner or operator of a retail food establishment to permit such inspections to be made, and when required, to furnish samples of any foods kept, sold, offered for sale, or served in such establishment which samples shall be examined or analyzed by or under the direction of the village clerk or his deputy, and a record of each such examination or analysis shall be made and kept on file in his office. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 21, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-61. - Food dispenser defined. 
    A food dispenser is hereby defined, for the purpose of this article, as any person that keeps for sale, sells and serves to the general public, for consumption on the premises, or on the sidewalk, or public way contiguous to said premises, any article of food or drink for human consumption. The word "serves" as used in this section, shall include the placing of such food for the convenience of the patron into any cup, glass, dish, plate, or other receptacle from which the patron may conveniently consume it. Restaurants, ordinaries, coffee houses, ice cream parlors, bakeries, taverns, clubs, lunch rooms, tea rooms, lunch stands, box lunch deliveries, luncheonettes, cafeterias and retail drugstores serving counter lunches and drinks shall be included among "food dispensers." 
(Ord. No. 105, § 1, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-62. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate the business of food dispenser without first having obtained a license to do so. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 2, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-63. - Application for license. 
    Written application for a license hereunder, which shall conform to the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses, shall be made to the village clerk. Such application shall contain the name and residence of the applicant, and if the applicant is a firm, of each member of same. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall contain the names and residences of its principal officers. Such application shall contain such further information as may be required by the village clerk in order to inform him fully as to the size and nature of the place to be used for the purposes of the business and the conditions, equipment and facilities for conducting the business therein, the health of persons to be employed and the regulations and facilities provided for them. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 2, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-64. - License fee. 
(a)  The annual license fee for food dispensers shall be as follows: 
(1)  Food dispensers offering service accommodations for ten persons or less and operators of taverns and clubs dispensing sandwiches only ..... $5.00 
(2)  Operators of bakeries ..... 5.00 
(3)  Food dispensers offering service accommodations for 11 persons or more ..... 5.00 
(b)  The term "service accommodations" as used in this section shall be held to mean and is hereby defined as the seating place where one patron or customer to be served can be seated or, in lieu of seating space, two lineal feet of counter space which may be used or occupied by one patron or customer to be served while standing; provided, that for the purpose of computing the number of service accommodations at a counter where no fixed seats or stools are provided, each such counter shall be considered as a separate unit and any fractional part of two lineal feet at a side or end shall be excluded. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 3, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-65. - When licenses expire. 
    A food dispenser's license shall expire on the 30th day of June of the year for which the same is issued. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 3, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-66. - Inspection required. 
    Before any license shall be issued, the village clerk, or his deputy, if such deputy is appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees of the village, shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises to be occupied by the applicant as a food dispenser, the equipment contained therein, the persons to be employed therein, the sanitary and hygienic features and conditions, and all other matters relating to the business which he considers it is necessary or proper to inquire into from the standpoint of health and sanitation. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 4, 6-13-55) 
State Law reference- Inspections authorized, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-3. 
Sec. 9-67. - Issuance of license. 
    If the village clerk, or his deputy, is satisfied, from such inspection, that the place where the business is to be conducted is in a sanitary condition and a fit and proper place for the business and that all the provisions of this article relating to the conduct of such business have been observed, he shall approve the application, and thereupon, upon the payment of the license fee herein provided, the mayor may issue a license to the applicant to conduct such business at such place during the year for which such license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 4, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-68. - License revocation. 
    The mayor may revoke a license issued hereunder at any time by notice in writing whenever it shall appear to his satisfaction from the recommendation of the village clerk or his deputy, or otherwise, that the licensee has violated the provisions of any law of the State of Illinois or of any ordinance of the village relating to the carrying on of the business of food dispenser and has failed to correct the same upon due notice from the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 4, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-69. - Quarterly inspections; inspection fees. 
    In addition to the preliminary inspection herein provided for, the village clerk shall cause an inspection to be made of the place and personnel employed therein three times each year for the purpose of determining whether all the requirements of this article and the health and sanitation laws of the State of Illinois are being complied with; and such inspections shall be made with special reference to the requirements of division 2 of this article. The charge for each inspection shall be $15.00 payable by the licensee at the time of inspection. The village shall receipt for all inspection fees received, through the inspector receiving the fee, upon a receipt to be furnished by the village clerk, and all such fees received shall be immediately accounted for to the village treasurer by the inspector and deposited with said village treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 4, 6-13-55; Ord. No. 458, 12-22-80) 
State Law reference- Inspections authorized, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-3. 
Secs. 9-70-9-76. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SANITATION 

Sec. 9-77. - Compliance required. 
    The conditions and regulations contained in this division shall be observed in all food dispensers' places or establishments. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 5, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-78. - Protection of food from contamination generally. 
    All food which is received and which is intended to be used and prepared for human consumption upon being received by any person, firm or corporation, shall be adequately protected from dust, flies, vermin and other insects. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 14, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-79. - Cleanliness of room where food served. 
    The room or place where food is sold or served for human consumption shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 15, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-80. - Dining room generally. 
    In the dining room there shall be adequate light and ventilation; the walls, ceilings, and floors shall be in good repair and clean, tables, counters, shelves and other furniture shall have clean surfaces, and be kept clean. All utensils, including urns and containers for milk, cream, coffee, and water, shall be made of materials that can be easily cleaned and disinfected. Foods during serving hours shall be handled or kept so that they are not exposed to contamination by dirt, flies, or vermin, or promiscuous handling by patrons. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 6, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-81. - Kitchen generally. 
    The kitchen shall have adequate light and ventilation, and the air flow shall always be from the dining room through the kitchen. The discharge from kitchen fans shall always be through a duct to a point above the roof line to protect the occupants of the building in which the establishment is located or adjoining buildings from nuisance. Ranges, refrigerators and other bulky equipment should be so arranged as not to obstruct the light and ventilation, and tables for clean and dirty dishes and food shall be so arranged that the dirty dishes will be as far removed from the food rack and clean dishes as may be possible. Ranges shall be hooded so that the cooking odors may be effectually carried off by a stack or an exhaust fan or a skylight immediately above. The walls and ceilings shall be in good repair and easily cleaned. The floor shall be of such construction (preferably impervious) that it may be kept clean at all times. The floors and walls should be proof against rats and vermin. Ranges, steam tables, shelves, racks, blocks, tables, or other machinery or furniture used in mixing, cutting, grinding, cooking or otherwise preparing the foods for service shall be of such material and construction that they may be kept scrupulously clean at all times. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 7, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-82. - Refrigerators. 
    Refrigerators shall be lined with impervious nonabsorbent material and adequately drained by indirect or broken connections with the sewer, and there shall be separate compartments for keeping such food materials as may unfavorably affect each other if kept together. Scrupulous cleanliness shall be maintained at all times. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 8, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-83. - Plumbing. 
    There shall be adequate plumbing facilities so that there is a sufficient supply of running hot and cold water for all washing purposes, and all fixtures, such as sinks, wash basins, etc., must be adequately trapped, vented and revented and properly connected to the sewer. All sinks in which greasy pots or dishes are washed must be connected to a catchbasin or be equipped with an approved water-jacket grease trap. Dish washers and all dish washing equipment, steam tables, coffee urns, water coolers and refrigerators, may discharge into the floor gutter or over a floor drain, and if connected solidly to the waste pipes or plumbing system must have traps and vents the same as other plumbing fixtures. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 9, 6-13-55) 
Cross reference- Plumbing regulations generally, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 9-84. - Cleanliness, health of employees. 
    All employees shall be clean in person and in clothing, and no person afflicted with any venereal, contagious or infectious disease in communicable form and no human carrier of bacillus diphtheria, bacillus Typhosus, bacillus dysenterine, bacillus enteritidis, bacillus paratyphosus, amoebic of bacilli dysentery, shall be employed in or about the preparing, handling, cooking or serving of foodstuffs or in the washing of the dishes or other utensils. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 10, 6-13-55) 
Cross reference- Diseased employees prohibited in alcoholic liquor establishments, § 3-36. 
Sec. 9-85. - Clothing of employees. 
    All persons who are engaged in preparing meals to be sold at food dispenser's establishment, shall wear suitable clothing which shall be clean and of a washable character or nature and used for that purpose only. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 16, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-86. - Practices of employees. 
    All employees in a food dispenser's establishment and all persons handling or serving food therein are prohibited from handling butter intended to be used for foods in such places in a manner which causes their hands to come in contact therewith, and from picking up glasses, cups or mixers with their fingers inserted therein, and from wiping dishes with soiled napkins or aprons, or with napkins or aprons that were previously used for any purpose and not relaundered since last used. No bakery goods shall be exposed for the purpose of exhibiting same in such places unless adequately protected against insects of all kinds and contamination by dust or handling by patrons. Such places shall not be so dusted or swept that dust will settle on food that is exposed. Dry sweeping in such places is hereby prohibited, and if indulged in shall subject both the proprietor or manager and the employee who actually does the sweeping to the penalty provided by section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 19, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-87. - Storage rooms and areas. 
(a)  All store rooms, or other rooms directly connected with the establishment shall be clean, dry, and kept in such a condition as not to affect unfavorably the foodstuffs used or the health of the employees or of the public. Yards, cellar or other areas directly connected with, or in close proximity to the establishment, shall be kept clean. 
(b)  Foodstuffs shall not be stored in a location that will render them unwholesome, and shall be elevated from the floor. Examination shall be made of all meats, canned-goods and other food materials to determine their purity and wholesomeness. The usual directions for condemnation and disposition of unwholesome foods shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 11, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-88. - Cleanliness of dishes, utensils. 
    Glasses, cups, dishes, knives, forks, spoons and other eating and drinking utensils, which are used more than once in any food dispensing establishment or any similar establishment shall be thoroughly washed and cleaned in such a way as to remove completely all visible foreign matter by either of the following methods: 
(a)  By mechanical dish washing machine which shall have a direct connection to hot water supply and which spray a fresh supply of hot rinse water direct on all sides of such dishes and eating and drinking utensils. 
(b)  By hand washing, which shall be done in warm water containing soap or other effective cleansing agent, and followed by rinsing in clean water of a temperature not below 170 degrees Fahrenheit for at least one minute, followed by draining. Provided, however, that in lieu of such rinsing in hot water, such dishes and utensils may be immersed for at least one minute in clean water to which has been added a chlorine disinfectant in such quantity as to yield approximately 100 parts per million of available chlorine (one and one-half ounce of a solution of chlorinated soda per gallon of wash water). 
(c)  By hand washing which shall be done in clean warm water containing an inorganic cleansing agent to which has been added a chlorine disinfectant in such quantity as to yield approximately 200 parts per million of available chlorine. The water shall be changed when dirty. The washing mixture shall at no time contain less than 35 parts per million of available chlorine. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 12, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-89. - Dishes, utensils to be washed after each use. 
    No glass, cup, dish, knife, fork, spoon or other eating or drinking vessel or utensils, after use by one patron in eating or drinking, shall be offered or permitted to be used by any other patron without such glass, cup, dish, knife, fork, spoon or other eating or drinking vessel or utensil having been first thoroughly washed and cleansed by either of the foregoing methods. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 12, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-90. - Poisonous polishing compounds, cleaning agents. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating, maintaining or conducting any hotel, club, restaurant, coffee house, lunchroom or any other eating place wherein food is served to the public, to use any ingredient or substance containing any sodium cyanide, potassium cyanide, oxalic acid, mercuric compound, or other poisonous substances, for the cleaning of nickel, copper, silverware or silver plated ware or other articles or utensils used for the service or preparation of food or foodstuffs. 
(b)  All polishes, cleaning fluids, or compounds, containing any matter or substance deleterious to health, sold or offered for sale in the Village of Montgomery, and used or intended for the polishing of silverware, kitchenware, and/or other articles or utensils used for the service or preparation of food or foodstuffs or used or intended for the polishing of any other articles, shall be sold only in containers to which shall be affixed a label conspicuous in appearance, containing the word "Poison" printed in red ink in letters of at least three-eighths of an inch in height, and containing an imprint of a skull and cross bones. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 13, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-91. - Freedom from vermin, deleterious matter. 
    Every food dispenser's establishment shall be kept free from rats, mice and vermin, and free from matter of a deleterious nature. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 17, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-92. - Protection from flies. 
    Every such establishment shall be kept reasonably free from flies, and the doors, windows and other openings of every such place shall, from the 15th day of April to the 15th day of November in each year, be fitted with wire window screens and self-closing wire screen doors. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 20, 6-13-55) 
Sec. 9-93. - Garbage disposal. 
    Every person owning or controlling any food dispenser's establishment where more than 20 guests or boarders are fed daily, shall cause all offal, table refuse, shells and animal or vegetable matter commonly known and described as garbage, to be placed in proper metallic cans, which shall be practically air and watertight, and shall cause all such cans or receptacles containing garbage to be placed for pickup and removal by the village in accordance with the provisions of this Code and directions or rules of the village clerk or his deputy relating to the disposition and removal of such substances; or shall dispose of such garbage by burning in a properly constructed crematory which shall have been approved by the village clerk or his deputy. 
(Ord. No. 105, § 18, 6-13-55) 
Cross reference- Garbage disposal generally, § 9-41 et seq. 
Secs. 9-94-9-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PRAIRIE GRASSES CONTROL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 872, §§ 2-5, adopted Oct. 25, 1999, enacted provisions which pertained to control of prairie grasses. Such ordinance did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as Art. V, §§ 9-111-9-117 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 9-111. - Prairie grass permits. 
    Prairie grass permits. 
(1)  Permit required: Notwithstanding any village ordinance to the contrary, prairie grasses as herein defined shall be permitted and not considered a weed for village ordinance purposes, if such grasses are maintained in conformance with this article. However, prairie grasses grown and maintained on more than one percent, in aggregate, of a lot, tract or parcel of land within the village not covered by a structure or structures shall be permitted only if a permit has been applied for and received from the village. Prairie grasses grown and maintained on one percent or less, in aggregate, of a lot, tract or parcel of land within the village not covered by a structure or structures shall be allowed without a permit. If prairie grasses are intermingled with other vegetation so as to make it impractical to measure for determining if the percentage is more or less than one percent, the entire bed or area of mixed vegetation shall be deemed to be prairie grasses for the purpose of the calculation. 
(2)  Definitions: For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
a.  Structure shall be defined as set forth in the Zoning Ordinance of the Village of Montgomery and consistent therewith, driveways and sidewalks are deemed not to be structures. 
b.  Prairie grasses shall mean plants and vegetation in the commonly accepted publications describing prairie grasses, including but not limited to the publications entitled, "Plants of the Chicago Region," by Floyd Swink and Gerould Wilhelm (1974), "Wildflowers of the Tallgrass Prairie, the Upper Midwest," by Sylvan T. Runkel and Dean M. Roosa (1989), and "Field Guide to North American Wildflowers, Eastern Region," by The Audubon Society (1979), "Native Illinois Herbs and Flora," by Illinois Department of Conservation, copies of which are on file and available for public inspection at the Village Hall of the Village of Montgomery. 
(3)  Setback: All prairie grasses shall have a mandatory setback of not less than 25 feet from any front, rear or side lot line. 
(4)  Application for permit: A person shall apply for such a permit by submitting to the village: a completed application supplied by the Village, and a site plan drawn to scale or dimensioned on sheets of paper no smaller than 81/2 × 11 inches and no larger than 24 × 36 inches which contain the location of property lines, location of plant materials, list of plant materials (common names), north arrow, location of structures and paved areas, distances of plant materials from property lines. The village staff shall review the application and site plan and issue a permit if it determines, in its sole discretion that the plan is consistent with surrounding land owners uses of property and a nuisance will not arise from the implementation of the plan. The applicant may appeal the denial of a permit to the village board. 
(5)  Compliance with permitted plan; revocation of permit: If, at any time, the implementation of a permitted plan exceeds that planting shown on the plan or if other weeds, plants or grass are allowed to grow to a height exceeding that allowed by the village weed ordinance, it shall be and is hereby deemed a nuisance and the permit shall automatically be revoked. Such a nuisance shall be a violation of this article. 
(6)  Term of permit: Any permit issued pursuant to this subsection shall be valid for five years at which time it must be renewed and a new permit fee paid. The permit may be terminated sooner pursuant to subsection (5) above. 
(7)  Annual cutting: It shall be a requirement of this section and a condition of the permit that the person to whom it is issued shall mow, cut or burn (in conformance with all other applicable regulations) the prairie grasses to the height set forth for other weeds, plants or grass in other village ordinances no less than once every 12 months. 
(8)  Maintenance of lot: It shall be a requirement of this article and a condition of the permit that the lot owner shall prevent encroachment of weeds, plants, grass and prairie grasses into a contiguous lot, tract or parcel of land, and shall be responsible for the maintenance of the weeds, plants, grass, prairie grasses without entering upon said contiguous lot, tract or parcel of land. 
(9)  Permit fee: The fee for a prairie grass permit shall be $75.00 and shall be paid upon application for the permit. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 2, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 9-112. - Control. 
    All prairie grass requiring permits pursuant to the provisions above, which are grown or maintained without permits, or weeds, plants or grass shall be cut, pulled, plowed under or otherwise destroyed as necessary so as to comply with the provisions of this article and the village shall be under no obligation to provide prior notice of violation to any party in violation of any section hereof. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 3, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 9-113. - Abatement. 
(a)  The village shall have the right to abate by cutting, pulling, plowing under, chemically spraying or otherwise destroying any existing prairie grasses grown or maintained without permits, and which violate the provisions of this article. If the village chooses to abate any existing prairie grasses grown or maintained without permits, a designee of the village shall first serve a notice by certified mail return receipt requested and by regular mail upon the owner of record at the address shown on the county tax rolls. 
Said notice shall: 
(1)  Demand the abatement of the nuisance within ten days after the date of mailing; and 
(2)  Provide that upon failure to abate the nuisance, the designee of the village may issue a citation and proceed to abate the nuisance at the owner's expense. 
(b)  If the nuisance is not abated within ten days after the notice has been mailed, the designee of the village may proceed to abate the nuisance, or cause such nuisance to be abated, keeping an account of the expense of abatement, and such expenses shall be charged to and paid by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 4, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 9-114. - Lien. 
    All costs incurred by the village for abatement, pursuant to this article, shall be a lien upon the property as provided in Chapter 65, Act 5, Sections 11-20-6 and 11-20-7, of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. This cost shall be a lien upon the real estate, affected superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens; provided, that within 60 days after such cost or expense is incurred, the village or person performing on behalf of the village, in his or its own name files a notice of lien in the office of the Kane or Kendall County Recorder of Deeds. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out (1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; (2) the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and (3) the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village. However, such lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Upon payment of the cost and expense (including costs and expenses of releasing the lien) by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
    The cost of the cutting shall not be a lien on the real estate affected unless a notice is personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the last preceding year. The notice shall be delivered or sent after the cutting of weeds on the property. The notice shall state the substance of this section and shall identify the property, by common description, and the location of the weeds to be cut. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 5, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 9-115. - Foreclosure of lien. 
    Property subject to a lien for unpaid cutting charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as in the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the village. 
    The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which a bill for weed cutting has remained unpaid 60 days after it has been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 5, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 9-116. - Exemption. 
    The provisions of this article requiring a prairie grass permit shall not be applicable with respect to any premises or lands that are classified for legal nonconforming farm or agricultural use, or lands owned by the State of Illinois or any department, agency, instrumentality or political subdivision thereof. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 5, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 9-117. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which such nuisance remains unabated. 
(Ord. No. 872, § 5, 10-25-99) 
ARTICLE VI. - NON-ORGANIC GRASS REGULATION 

Sec. 9-118. - Installation of non-organic grass substitutes on private property. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Non-organic grass substitutes shall mean synthetic turf products made to resemble natural grass turf lawns. 
(2)  Permitted non-organic grass substitutes shall mean those products specifically designed and manufactured to be installed in lieu of grass on a permanent or near permanent basis. Said products must be demonstrated to withstand temperature extremes, weather events (snow, ice and rain) and installation must be conducted in a manner that insures said products will not be easily removed, blown or torn away from the surface it is covering during storm events. Said products must be water permeable to allow for drainage through the surface of the product of any liquids deposited on the surface of the product and must not cause surface soil erosion. Examples include, but are not limited to, Astroturf &reg;, playground poured in place rubber surfaces and recycled rubber mulch substitutes. 
(3)  Prohibited non-organic grass substitutes shall mean any synthetic turf products which do not meet the definition of a permitted non-organic grass substitute. Examples include, but are not limited to, indoor/outdoor carpeting. 
(b)  Control of non-organic grass substitutes. 
(1)  Non-organic grass substitutes that do not meet the requirements of subsection (a)(2) are hereby prohibited. 
(c)  Violations; fines and penalties. 
(1)  Any violation of any of the terms and provisions of this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be penalized as provided in section 1-8 of the Village Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1592, § 1, 11-12-13) 
Chapter 91/2 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1123, § 1, adopted May 24, 2004, provided for the addition of a Ch. 21, pertaining to the historic preservation commission. Such provisions were redesignated by the editor as Ch. 91/2, §§ 91/2-1-91/2-4, in order to maintain the alphabetical sequence of chapter titles within the Code. 

Sec. 91/2-1. - Commission-Established. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-48.2-1 et seq., there is hereby created and established an historic preservation commission which shall consist of nine members, seven of whom shall be residents of the village and two of whom need not be members of the village. All such members shall have demonstrated an interest in historic preservation. Members of the commission shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board. The members of the commission shall elect from among themselves a chair and vice-chair of the commission, to serve until the end of their respective terms, or until the members of the commission elect a new chair and/or vice-chair, whichever is earlier. 
    All members of the commission shall be appointed on the basis of demonstrated expertise, experience or interest in the areas of archaeology, architecture, art, building construction, engineering, finance, historical and architectural preservation, history, law, planning or real estate. Representatives from each of the various village departments shall advise the commission when required. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 1769, § 1, 5-8-17) 
Sec. 91/2-2. - Same-Terms; compensation. 
(a)  Terms of office. Terms of office of members of the commission shall be three years. Resident members of the commission shall serve terms of initially: three members appointed for one year, two members appointed for two years, two members appointed for three years. Members may be reappointed for consecutive terms. Two additional members shall be appointed who are not required to be residents; one of whom shall serve an initial term until 2019 and one of whom shall serve an initial term until 2021. Upon the expiration of said initial terms all subsequent appointments shall be for three years and may be reappointed for consecutive terms. The village president, with the advice and consent of the village board, shall have the power to remove any member of said commission for any reason, at any time, including, but not limited to, for cause including excessive nonattendance at commission meetings. 
(b)  Compensation. Members of the commission shall serve without pay, but may be reimbursed by the village for necessary expenses incurred in conjunction with their duties, as approved in advance by the village. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 1769, § 1, 5-8-17) 
Sec. 91/2-3. - Same-Organization, rules and meetings. 
(a)  Rules. The commission may establish such rules as are necessary for the orderly conduct of its business which are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter and any such rules established shall be in writing. 
(b)  Meetings. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public as in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act. 
(c)  Records. The commission shall keep a record, which shall be open to public view, of its resolutions, proceedings, and actions. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 5-24-04) 
Sec. 91/2-4. - Same-Jurisdiction and authority. 
    The scope of the commission's authority shall be as follows: 
(1)  To maintain a system for the survey and inventory of historic places or items. 
(2)  To educate individuals as to the significance of historic structures or sites, and recommend style, color, building materials or exterior features that will be compatible with historic conditions. 
(3)  To respond to the request of the director of community development for comments regarding changes, amendments or variances to the village's comprehensive plan, development policies or zoning ordinance and then only as such is pertinent to the village's historic condition(s). 
(4)  To initiate, review and to make recommendations to the village board for the nominations of property to the national register or the designation of local landmarks within the corporate authorities. 
(5)  To develop programs with the advice and consent of the village board to encourage the continuing education of the citizens of the village with respect to the historic heritage of the village. 
(6)  To retain such specialists as may be required from time to time upon approval by the village board. 
(7)  To induce by contract or other consideration the creation of covenants or restrictions binding on land. 
(8)  To receive funds on behalf of the village from federal, state and private sources for deposit in a separate account of the village to be referred to as the preservation fund, which funds shall only be loaned or expended by the commission with approval of the village board for such purposes as are herein set forth; and in the event the commission shall be dissolved, then any amounts remaining in said fund shall be applied by the village board to further the purposes of this chapter. If any amounts remain in said fund after a period of one year following the commission's dissolution, then such funds may be supplied by the village board for such general corporate purposes as it may deem appropriate. 
(9)  To cooperate with other governmental bodies or agencies and not for profit organizations with purposes similar to those set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 5-24-04) 
Sec. 91/2-5. - Landmark designations-Procedures and standards. 
(a)  Procedure: 
(1)  Any person, group of persons or association, or the historic preservation commission (hereinafter referred to as the commission) on its own initiative, may propose landmark designation for any improvement or site which is located within the corporate limits of the village and which may have historic significance as set forth in the criteria for evaluation. The application for landmark designation shall be in writing and shall contain such information and be in such form as the commission shall, by rule, prescribe from time to time. Forms required for landmark designation shall be supplied by the director of community development, upon request. 
Any structure already on the national register of historic sites shall be a designated landmark, subject to a public hearing. 
(2)  The application for landmark designation shall be filed with the director of community development. Within five working days of filing, the director of community development shall transmit the application to the commission for review and public hearing. 
(3)  Within 30 days after filing of the application for landmark designation, the commission shall contact the property owner (if the application was made by a party other than the property owner) to provide a copy of the application for landmark designation and request a response from the owner in writing as to whether or not the property owner consents or objects to such a designation. 
(4)  Within 60 days after filing of the application for landmark designation, the commission shall hold a public hearing on the question of proposed landmark designation. 
(5)  Prior to the public hearing on the application for landmark designation, the commission shall review the application and any additional information on the improvement or site proposed for landmark designation and make a report containing preliminary findings on the historic, architectural and aesthetic significance of the improvement. 
(6)  Notice of the public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the village, not less than 15 days nor more than 30 days in advance of the date of the hearing. The notice shall identify the applicant, property owners, property affected and shall describe the proposed amendment. 
The applicant shall provide a list to the director of community development, along with addressed envelopes with return receipts (certified mail), of the owner of the subject property and the owners of record of all properties situated either 250 feet (excluding rights-of-way) from the property that is the subject of the public hearing or two lots deep, whichever is the greater distance, and the director of community development shall mail to said owners a written notice of the public hearing not less than ten days prior to the hearing. 
The director of community development shall make every reasonable effort to comply with the notice provisions set forth in this section. Failure to comply with any of the notice provisions, except for the publishing of the legal notice in the newspaper and the notice to the owner of the subject property, shall not render any amendment invalid. 
(7)  The public hearing shall be conducted by the commission and a record of such proceedings shall be preserved in such manner as the commission shall, by rule, prescribe from time to time. 
(8)  The commission shall make written findings of fact and shall submit same, together with its recommendations, to the village board within 15 days of the date of the public hearing. Applications for a local landmark which do not have property owner consent shall require a supermajority vote of the commission to recommend approval of the designation of landmark. A supermajority shall be defined as three-quarters of the commission members. 
(9)  Within 120 days of the filing of the application, the village board shall grant or deny the application for landmark designation.
